item.title: Best Terraria Ranged Weapons
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

There's something deliciously smug about wielding the best Terraria ranged weapons. While melee players are sweating it out in close quarters and mages are chugging mana potions like they're at an all-night rave, you're standing comfortably out of reach, raining down arrows, bullets, or bees with barely a scratch on your armor. It's the class for anyone who enjoys watching health bars melt while staying three steps ahead of the danger.

That's not to say it's easy. Ranged combat is a balancing act between conserving ammo, picking the best Terraria accessories for your build, and stocking up on enough arrows or bullets to avoid the dreaded "click" of an empty chamber mid-boss fight. But when it all comes together, nothing feels quite as powerful. From simple ore bows to weapons that literally summon storms, the marksman's journey is one of precision, chaos, and plenty of smug grins.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • Pre-Hardmode
    • Platinum Bow
    • The Bee's Knees
    • Hellwing Bow
  • Hardmode
    • Daedalus Stormbow
    • Onyx Blaster
    • Phantasm
    • S.D.M.G.

Pre-Hardmode

Platinum Bow

  • Damage: 13
  • Knockback: 0
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 25 (Fast)
  • Velocity: 6.6
  • Ammo: Arrows

Forget the wooden twig you start with, as the Platinum Bow is your first taste of real power. Made from just eight Platinum Bars, it delivers enough punch to make the Eye of Cthulhu feel more like target practice than a boss fight. It's easy to craft, doesn't ask much of you beyond a bit of mining, and instantly transforms you from hapless survivor into a hunter who means business. Pair it with Flaming Arrows for a fiery upgrade or Jester's Arrows to pierce crowds, and you'll sail through those chaotic early nights.

It's not flashy, but that's exactly the appeal. Early ranged combat is about consistency, and the Platinum Bow never lets you down. Think of it as your training wheels before Terraria decides to throw a real challenge at you. You'll eventually outgrow it, but for a weapon you can forge on day two, it's absurdly good at keeping you alive and on the front foot.

The Bee's Knees

  • Damage: 23
  • Knockback: 3
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 23 (Fast)
  • Velocity: 8
  • Ammo: Arrows

Every ranged player remembers the first time they loosed an arrow with The Bee's Knees and watched the screen fill with buzzing chaos. Dropped by Queen Bee, this jungle treasure transforms plain old Wooden Arrows into swarms of homing bees that ricochet off walls and sting anything unlucky enough to be nearby. Suddenly, accuracy doesn't matter quite so much because you can just fire in the general direction of trouble and let your insect army handle the rest.

It's perfect for messy fights. Goblin Army invasion? Bees everywhere. Skeletron's skull and hands? Our friendly Bumbles chew through them like paper. Even Terraria bosses that usually require tight aim feel easier because your insect army simply doesn't miss. It's not the most elegant weapon, but it's certainly one of the most fun, and mid-game Terraria is exactly where a bit of spectacle makes the grind feel worthwhile.

Hellwing Bow

  • Damage: 22
  • Knockback: 5.5
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 13 (Very Fast)
  • Velocity: 6
  • Ammo: Arrows

If you're heading into the Underworld, you'll want something with a bit of bite, and the Hellwing Bow more than delivers. Pulled from Shadow Chests, it transforms Wooden Arrows into fiery bats that pierce through everything in their path without slowing down. Suddenly, those cheap arrows you've been hoarding turn into deadly projectiles capable of hitting multiple enemies at once. When you're staring down the Wall of Flesh, those piercing bats feel like a cheat code.

It does take a little adjustment. The bats don't fly in perfectly straight lines like arrows, and their arcing paths can throw you off at first. But once you get the hang of it, the Hellwing Bow becomes indispensable. It's the ultimate pre-Hardmode boss killer, equipped with a single-click auto fire, which is usually reserved for Hardmode alternatives.

Hardmode

Daedalus Stormbow

  • Damage: 38
  • Knockback: 2.25
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 19 (Very Fast)
  • Velocity: 12.5
  • Ammo: Arrows

If there's one weapon that makes you feel like you've broken Terraria, it's the Daedalus Stormbow. Dropped by Hallowed Mimics, this unassuming bow calls down arrow rain from the heavens. Pair it with Holy Arrows, and suddenly you're orchestrating meteor showers of destruction. The Destroyer barely stands a chance as its segments are pummeled from above, each shot multiplying into falling stars. It's chaos, but the good kind.

What makes the Stormbow so beloved is that it rewards creativity. Build a flat arena, give the sky some clearance, and watch bosses dissolve under the deluge. Even with simpler arrows, it's wildly strong and feels almost unfair for early Hardmode.

Onyx Blaster

  • Damage: 24
  • Knockback: 6.5
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 48 (Extremely Slow)
  • Velocity: 14
  • Ammo: Bullets

Don't be fooled by the damage drop-off on paper; the Onyx Blaster steps up as your mid-Hardmode workhorse. An upgrade to the Shotgun with two Dark Shards and 10 Souls of Night, this beast spits out a spread of bullets and follows it up with a dark explosive blast for good measure. Crafted with Souls of Night and Dark Shards, it's one of those weapons that feels purpose-built for mowing down anything in your path.

The best thing about the Onyx Blaster is how adaptable it is. Load it with Ichor Bullets to shred boss defenses or Crystal Bullets to split each shot into even more damage. The additional explosive dark projectile guarantees impact even if your spread misses, which makes it forgiving in hectic battles. It's the kind of mid-game weapon you'll hold onto long after you technically have upgrades, simply because it's that satisfying to use.

Phantasm

  • Damage: 50
  • Knockback: 2
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 12 (Very Fast)
  • Velocity: 20
  • Ammo: Arrows
  • Bonus: 66% chance to save ammo

Near the top of the ranged food chain sits the Phantasm, a bow that spits arrows out in torrents. Crafted from 18 Vortex Fragments in an Ancient Manipulator, it launches rapid volleys, each shot spawning bonus homing arrows for free. The effect is overwhelming. Your screen fills with arrows, bosses evaporate under constant pressure, and suddenly you feel less like an archer and more like a living artillery cannon.

Of course, it's hungry. You have a small chance each shot to save ammo, but the Phantasm otherwise eats arrows faster than you can craft them. Some may say that's part of the charming challenge. Fortunately, you won't need many to humiliate your enemies, especially with Luminite Arrows in your pocket. This is the ranged endgame fantasy, granting you the smug satisfaction of watching the Moon Lord melt like butter.

S.D.M.G.

  • Damage: 85
  • Knockback: 2.5
  • Critical chance: 14%
  • Speed: 5 (Extremely Fast)
  • Velocity: 12
  • Ammo: Bullets
  • Bonus: 66% chance to save ammo

Beating the Moon Lord is no small feat, as the Space Dolphin Machine Gun is the perfect endgame gun to give you a pat on the back. Dropped by the big bad final boss, it boasts one of the fastest fire rates in the game and absurd base damage, meaning it can shred health bars before enemies even realize they're under attack. Despite its playful design, it's a powerhouse that turns bullets into a relentless stream of pain.

Of course, the S.D.M.G. has one big caveat: ammo. This thing chews through bullets faster than any other weapon, so keeping it fed becomes a logistical challenge. But when paired with high-end rounds like Luminite or Chlorophyte Bullets, the DPS is off the charts, so you shouldn't need to spend too many. It's strong, stylish, hilarious, and deeply satisfying to use.

Ranged combat is Terraria at its most efficient. Why risk your neck with other Terraria weapon types when you can fill the air with arrows, bullets, or bees and watch enemies crumble from a safe distance? Sure, you'll burn through ammo and your piggy bank might feel the strain, but few things compare to the feeling of staying untouched while bosses drop like clay pigeons.

Whether you're orchestrating divine arrow showers or letting a space dolphin unload on the Moon Lord, the marksman's path is one of precision and spectacle. It's chaotic, stylish, and just a little bit cheeky.

item.title: Best Terraria Melee Weapons
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

A simple class that's also the most reckless, there's a skill curve to the best Terraria melee weapons. Instead of hiding behind a staff or bow, you are charging face-first into danger, trading your health bar for glorious damage. It is the class for anyone who loves brute force, big crits, and feeling like a walking blender.

Getting up close and personal isn't just about swinging blindly. Terraria's melee arsenal is surprisingly diverse, ranging from oversized swords that cleave through entire boss arenas to yoyos, spears, boomerangs, and flails that control space. In true Terraria fashion, melee does not necessarily mean you need to be in the thick of the action. Plenty of the best blades sling projectiles across the screen when you jump from Pre-Hardmode to Hardmode, letting you play safe while keeping that melee identity.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • Pre-Hardmode
    • Terragrim
    • Volcano
    • Sunfury
  • Hardmode
    • Terra Blade
    • Solar Eruption
    • Zenith

Pre-Hardmode

Terragrim

  • Damage: 17
  • Knockback: 3
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 25 (Fast)

Terragrim is the ultimate pre-boss jackpot. Found rarely in Enchanted Sword Shrines, it attacks at a speed so absurd that the modest damage stat barely matters. It is not craftable, it is not guaranteed, and it may never appear in your world, but if you are fortunate enough to stumble across one, it changes everything.

This blade's rapid swings chew through enemies before they can touch you, and against early Terraria bosses like Eye of Cthulhu, you'll feel untouchable. Terragrim is not a weapon you plan for; it's a sword that happens to you, but it is the clearest example of the sandbox game rewarding exploration with outrageous power spikes.

Volcano

  • Damage: 40
  • Knockback: 6.5
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 40 (Very Slow)

Forged from Hellstone mined in the Underworld, the Volcano, otherwise known as the Fiery Greatsword on handheld platforms, is your midgame bruiser. It swings slowly but covers a huge arc, letting you tag multiple enemies at once while also applying the On Fire debuff for steady damage over time. Few pre-Hardmode swords feel as hefty in hand, and the extra reach gives you confidence against mobs that like to close space quickly.

More than just a strong weapon, Volcano is also a crucial ingredient in Night's Edge, itself the definitive pre-Hardmode sword. Even if you do not lean on it long term, crafting one is a natural step in melee progression. Think of it as a stepping stone and a statement that you are ready for Terraria's tougher encounters.

Sunfury

  • Damage: 64
  • Knockback: 6.75
  • Critical chance: 11%
  • Speed: 45 (Very Slow)

Sunfury is the most damaging melee weapon you can grab in Pre-Hardmode, full stop. Found in Shadow Chests or fished up from Obsidian Lock Boxes, this fiery flail swings through walls, pierces multiple enemies, and inflicts the On Fire debuff in addition to its initial smack. It makes quick work of events and bosses alike, letting you hold your ground instead of constantly dodging.

Unlike the Volcano, Sunfury also keeps you at a safer distance. The extended flail chain allows you to swap out tankiness for the best Terraria accessories that boost damage, since you will not always be face-to-face with enemies. It is the definition of dominance before Hardmode, making the Wall of Flesh fight far less intimidating.

Hardmode

Terra Blade

  • Damage: 85
  • Knockback: 6.5
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 18 (Very Fast)

Terra Blade turns melee into safe pressure. Forged from True Excalibur, True Night's Edge, and the Broken Hero Sword, it fires a green wave on every swing, giving you full melee scaling while landing hits at range. The handling is crisp, the DPS is reliable, and it feels heroic from the first craft.

Use it to tidy post-Plantera progression, to farm Eclipse drops, and to steamroll events while you build toward endgame fragments. It is the Swiss Army Knife of melee weapons, blending crowd control with boss focus without asking for fancy setups, and just one of many ingredients for the best sword in the game.

Solar Eruption

  • Damage: 105
  • Knockback: 6.75
  • Critical chance: 4%
  • Speed: 20 (Very Fast)

Solar Eruption is a pillar craft that bends the rules in your favour. The flaming chain pierces, lingers, and hits through walls while applying the Daybroken debuff for even heavier damage over time than On Fire. Reach, safety, and uptime combine into a tool that trivializes many late fights.

Thread it through blocks to shred crowds and tag bosses from apparent safety. It is outstanding for events and pillar clearing, where cover and density would normally slow you down. Few melee picks match its blend of control and sustained damage.

Zenith

  • Damage: 190
  • Knockback: 6.5
  • Critical chance: 14%
  • Speed: 30 (Average)

Existing between satisfying and showboating, Zenith is the victory lap. Crafted from a collection of ten iconic blades, including Terra Blade, Starfury, Seedler, Meowmere, Star Wraty, Influx Waver, The Horseman's Blade, Bee Keeper, Enchanted Sword, and the humble Copper Shortsword, it summons a storm of swords that chews through anything on screen. The performance is outrageous, and the animation feels like a reward for the entire journey.

Use it to close out moons, events, and farming with total authority. Zenith is deliberate excess, which is exactly the point. If you have assembled the lineage, you have earned the strongest toy in the sandbox.

Melee in Terraria is a journey from crude but satisfying swings to screen-filling spectacles. Pre-Hardmode gives you a taste of variety with blades that drop stars, flails that scatter mobs, and Night's Edge as the badge of progress. By Hardmode, your kit transforms into legendary blades and celestial crafts that let you fight from safety without ever losing the melee identity.

The appeal is simple. Compared to all other Terraria weapon types, you are always in the thick of it, standing toe to toe with bosses rather than hanging back. Every upgrade feels like a tangible power spike, and the final reward in Zenith is a pure celebration of everything you have built. If you enjoy high stakes, close calls, and the satisfaction of carving through enemies with your own two hands, melee is the class that never stops giving.

item.title: Best Terraria Summoner Weapons
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Like any good manager, delegation is one of your best tools. The best Terraria summoner weapons thrive not by swinging the sharpest blade or firing the fastest bullet, but by putting others to work. Each staff or whip you pick up is less about your own might and more about the team you assemble, from humble birds and frogs to celestial dragons. It is a playstyle built on patience and planning, rewarding those who prefer to orchestrate the fight rather than charge headfirst into it.

That is not to say life as a summoner is easy. The class often walks a fine line between feeling underpowered and overpowered, depending on the stage of the game and how well you support your minions with the right gear. But when it all clicks, few things match the satisfaction of watching an army you raised tear through bosses while you stand back, whip in hand, guiding the carnage.

Before we get into the journey best taken from Pre-Hardmode to Hardmode, it's worth understanding the difference between a minion and a sentry. Sentries are stationary, stronger for defending a single point during wave-based events, but require re-summoning if you relocate. Thanks to the added mobility, minions are generally better, following you into battle. It entirely depends on whether you prefer to lead from the back or the front. Regardless, you can summon multiple of the same unit to better stack your odds.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • Pre-Hardmode
    • Finch Staff
    • Ballista Rod
    • Vampire Frog Staff
    • Imp Staff
  • Hardmode
    • Spider Staff
    • Queen Spider Staff
    • Raven Staff
    • Stardust Dragon Staff

Pre-Hardmode

Finch Staff

  • Damage: 7
  • Mana cost: 10
  • Knockback: 4
  • Velocity: 10
  • Speed: 36 (Very Slow)
  • Summon type: Minion

The Finch Staff is the earliest taste of summoner life for many players, dropping from Living Trees with a bit of luck. It might not seem much at first, summoning a lone bird minion to hover overhead and peck at enemies, but it gives you a companion long before most other classes find something reliable. It is a gentle introduction to the idea of indirect combat, and a handy tool for those who want to feel like a summoner from the very start.

Stats are modest, with 7 base damage and zero knockback, meaning it will not carry you into midgame. Still, for something acquired almost immediately, it punches above its weight and provides a constant stream of chip damage that adds up in early fights. It is hardly spectacular, but it sets the tone for the summoner path and makes you hungry for stronger companions.

Ballista Rod

  • Damage: 30
  • Mana cost: 5
  • Knockback: 4.7
  • Velocity: 1
  • Speed: 30 (Average)
  • Summon type: Sentry

The Ballista Rod is obtained from the Tavernkeep once you have beaten the Goblin Army, and it marks the point where summoners begin to appreciate the power of sentries. Dropping a ballista turret changes how you approach fights, letting you cover choke points or add extra pressure in boss arenas with piercing bolts that subdue multiple enemies at once.

Unlike minions, sentries stay fixed to the ground, so clever placement becomes just as important as raw power. It takes some grinding to be able to summon more than one sentry at a time, such as the War Table granting the Strategist buff and increasing your capacity by one, but the benefit here is that this doesn't count towards your minion limit. Mix and match with multiple staves and you'll be well on your way to victory.

Vampire Frog Staff

  • Damage: 11
  • Mana cost: 10
  • Knockback: 5
  • Velocity: 10
  • Speed: 36 (Very Slow)
  • Summon type: Minion

This is where pre-Hardmode summoning starts to get serious. The Vampire Frog Staff, obtained during the Blood Moon event by defeating Zombie Merman or Wandering Eye Fish, unleashes frogs that leap aggressively at enemies, tearing through them with surprising speed. They might not look intimidating, but these amphibians carry you further than any bird or slime, and suddenly the summoner class feels less like a gimmick and more like a viable playstyle.

Each frog deals 11 damage and strikes quickly, giving you rapid crowd control against swarms of enemies. For the pre-Hardmode stretch, they feel like a revelation. If you can survive the Blood Moon long enough to snag this staff, you will have one of the most dependable weapons of the entire early game.

Imp Staff

  • Damage: 17
  • Mana cost: 10
  • Knockback: 2
  • Velocity: 10
  • Speed: 36 (Very Slow)
  • Summon type: Minion

By the time you reach the Underworld, the Imp Staff becomes the standout pre-Hardmode choice. It is crafted with 17 Hellstone Bars, meaning you will need to brave lava lakes and fire imps, but the payoff is worth it. The summoned imps shoot fireballs from a distance, dealing reliable damage without getting into harm's way. It's a powerful weapon for Terraria boss fights, particularly against the Wall of Flesh where constant ranged pressure makes all the difference.

With a strong base damage and piercing fireballs that cut through enemies, the Imp Staff stands head and shoulders above other pre-Hardmode options. Its ability to keep enemies at range is a marked improvement over frogs and slimes, and it transitions neatly into early Hardmode before you find something stronger.

Hardmode

Spider Staff

  • Damage: 26
  • Mana cost: 10
  • Knockback: 3
  • Velocity: 10
  • Speed: 36 (Very Slow)
  • Summon type: Minion

Once you defeat the Wall of Flesh and enter Hardmode, the Spider Staff is often your first true upgrade. Pieced together from the 16 Spider Fans you farm from the new spider caves, the staff summons spiders that scuttle rapidly across the ground to overwhelm foes. These arachnids shred enemies at close range and make mechanical bosses far more manageable than they might otherwise be.

Each spider deals 26 damage with fast bites, and the fact that they stick to enemies makes them particularly effective against single targets. Their only drawback is their limited range, but inflicting the Acid Venom debuff for six health per second means they'll make short work of their current target. Add the right armour and best Terraria accessories, and you can summon a small army to pave the way forward.

Queen Spider Staff

  • Damage: 26
  • Mana cost: 10
  • Knockback: 7.5
  • Velocity: 14
  • Speed: 30 (Average)
  • Summon type: Sentry

Crafted from 24 Spider Fangs, this staff is an essential part of any Hardmode summoner's toolkit. It raises a sentry that shoots eggs, which explode on impact, cause damage over time via the Acid Venom debuff, and spawn two baby spiders that latch onto the enemy. Most importantly, sentries do not consume minion slots, so you can pair a Queen Spider turret with a full roster of minions for a devastating mix.

The barrage of eggs inflicting base damage and multiple spiders spawning to chip away at enemies make the Queen Spider Staff a constant source of supplementary damage that scales beautifully with your growing minion count.

Raven Staff

  • Damage: 55
  • Mana cost: 10
  • Knockback: 3
  • Velocity: 10
  • Speed: 28 (Average)
  • Summon type: Minion

When Pumpkins are falling and Halloween looms, the Raven Staff becomes a spooky powerhouse. Dropped from the Pumpkin Moon event, it summons ravens that swoop down with ferocity and deal heavy hits. It is a weapon that immediately propels summoners into late Hardmode viability, giving you the tools to melt bosses and invasion waves alike.

Each raven deals a whopping amount of damage and attacks swiftly from the air, providing relentless harassment to enemies. With enough summons in play, the screen quickly becomes a blur of feathers and strikes that would make Alfred Hitchcock proud. While event-dependent, the Raven Staff is a serious upgrade that can carry you all the way to the endgame if you invest in supporting gear.

Stardust Dragon Staff

  • Damage: 40
  • Mana cost: 10
  • Knockback: 2
  • Velocity: 10
  • Speed: 36 (Very Slow)
  • Summon type: Minion

The Stardust Dragon Staff is the crown jewel of summoning, the weapon that makes you feel truly unstoppable. Crafted from 18 Stardust Fragments after defeating the Lunar Events, it summons a celestial dragon that grows longer with every minion slot you invest. Rather than multiple creatures, you channel all your summoning capacity into one devastating beast that dominates the battlefield.

Each segment of the dragon adds 40 base damage, and when fully extended, it becomes one of the most destructive forces in Terraria. Its constant sweeping attacks obliterate enemies and bosses alike, leaving little room for resistance. It is the definitive summoner's staff for endgame players, rising above just about all Terraria weapons, and a fitting reward for those who chose the path of delegation.

Summoner weapons transform Terraria into a different game, one where your success depends less on personal reflexes and more on the strength of your companions. From tiny birds and frogs in the early days to celestial dragons at the peak of power, these tools of delegation turn you into the ultimate battlefield commander. Master them, and you will never need to lift a sword again.
